title: Benchmarks, wikis, and open-source causal discovery

author: Patrik Hoyer, Helsinki Institute for Information Technology

segmentation: Yeah, so my name is Patrick Hoyer and I work on causal discovery methods and.
For reasons that will become clear, but later in the talk I was asked to provide some general comments on the.
The causality Workbench and the.
Repository that Isabel and her coworkers are.
Building and I'm afraid this is going to be a very non technical talk.
I'm sorry bout that and.
No equations and not very much about actually about sort of cause causal discovery per say, but more about how we might collaborate, how we might build a collaborative system for evaluating.

My only excuse for sort of taking up 50 minutes of valuable skiing time is that I think this is an important topic and actually building building and improve.
Methods for evaluating these.
Methods.
Alright, so the basically I mean the causal discovery problem as I understand it, to get on the same page.

Basically there's some underlying underlying data generating system and we've heard heard this described already on several occasions occasions this morning so that we only have some data, non experimental or experimental data and our task is really to infer this causal system to be able to make some causal predictions, and especially if you only have non experimental data, that is an extremely.
Difficult inverse problem and we need strong priors or assumptions to be able to succeed in this problem.
So.
It's a bit of a work around, but.
Maybe I'll get an extra minute for that, so the.

Obviously, since we need a lot of assumptions, the question is how well do these methods perform, and you can show of course that in simulations if you actually make data that have these assumptions built in, then you can show that these methods reliably detect some type of structure in the causal system.
But of course many people are sceptical and critical about this approach, and in particular I guess the question is that how well does real data actually have the properties.
That are assumed by these causal discovery methods.
And to test this, as you've heard, basically in addition to the data, you need some type of ground truth, some type of background knowledge, and what the actual correct result should be and so.
So it's not is not as easy as testing methods for regression classification, density estimation, or you can just leave out part of your data and and do it on that.
So basically I think there's a need for for this type of causal discovery repository that collects data sets and test problems that we can use to see how well we're actually doing on on real data.
And so.
So with this in mind, there was some year and a half ago that I wrote a small grant proposal suggesting some building a system like this.
And.
The basic basic structure of the system was something like the following.
The idea was that there would be.
Our problems and solutions, so the problems are called tasks and social solutions are called algorithms.
Tasks would basically be some real or simulated data and will be very precisely defined.
Exactly what the algorithm should try to do with that data.
It would be precisely defined how the results are going to be scored.
What's a good result, and what's the bad result.
So for real data, what we need is some type of information from the people that provided the data about what is actually.
Presumed to be the true causal structure.
In addition, maybe some reasonable assumptions.
Or what about what the data actually might be like and the algorithms on the other hand, should you know have description of what they do?
And specifically a very well defined input output relationship, so you know which algorithms you actually can apply on which tasks.

And preferably open source code that anybody could could investigate, but at the very least some executable files that anyone could basically take and apply these algorithms to any of the tasks they are compatible with and actually compare and see how well they do against each other so.
So this was the basic idea and the small grant was eventually awarded.
But of course what I also then would also have.
And was that?
I realize that there was already this project going on, so that was.
Are actually a nice thing, I think because this this project has gotten off.
I think that a very nice start.
As you heard, there are already quite a number of datasets that have been collected.
Tasks to be solved.
And the two challenges, the one in the spring.
And the one now for the NIPS challenge have gathered a number of different solution approaches to these these tasks.
So I think it's in.
It's an excellent effort on behalf of the coordinator on behalf of the team and on behalf.

Of course, everyone who submitted something, and so I think that of course with a small community like this, I think it's obvious that there's no point in sort of setting up any type of parallel systems, and the only reasonable thing is for me to try to do whatever I can to help with setting up and furthering this this project.

Needed, so I think it's.

So what follows are basically my some thoughts on what some of these principles are that I think might be useful to consider.
In building the.

History, so the first principle that I would like to mention is basically that the idea that all contributors and all users know that all the material and all versions of the material are always available.
So I think I think there is a point to be made for storing all of the material on the site rather than as links to outside outside material.
This is a number of advantages.
One is that it eliminates the problem of links going.
Broke that is breaking down, which I think is actually if you look at various sort of repository projects.

It's actually quite a common problem, and of course the problem is that people move, you know, they change universities they leave for industry and so on, and and in that kind of situation it's quite common that the actual.
Material, then is sort of glossed in the process, and then it sort of is very bad for the spirit of the repository.
I'm not sure to what extent sort of the.
Little bit of the sort of inactivity on a repository and then the.
Number of broken links is sort of what the causal relationships there are, but there's definitely a positive correlation.
I think.
I think in this in this regard so.
Also what you can have is if you have all the material on site you can have full revisioning versioning of all the materials so you can actually see exactly who did what and.
And at what time?
So, in a scientific context where you're actually interested in, you know who came up with what, ideas with what algorithms.
I think it's extremely important that you know exactly what material was put put on, at what time.
And this is this is easy to do if you have all the material online.
Also, it allows full downloading so that anyone can basically backup backup the system.
The.
2nd.

Property that I think is important to think about is that, especially if you have full versioning of all the material, there's not so much a need for you know, very strict technical restrictions on who can do what in this system.
Because you can always go back, you can always say, oh, that was not a good thing.
So we can.
We can revert to the earlier version and So what you can have is rather you can have sort of socially agreed upon rules of what kind of behavior is possible.

So for instance changing someone elses code package, uploading a new version without their consent is probably not something that you want anyone to do, but you don't have to explicitly restrict that.
Technically what you have to do is you have to have some rules saying that that's not.
Appropriate behavior, of course.
If someone doesn't play along with the rules, then you can exclude them.

The main point of this is that basically anyone can then help with any part of the project, so there doesn't have to be very strict division that the project team leaders are basically working on writing all the documentation, clarifying all the rules in the conventions, putting up the graphics in the design of the system, the structure.
But anyone can actually help with this, which actually helps sort of build.
Build it so that everyone sort of agrees to what what the actual.
Our system is like.
And the Third Point that I wanted to make was sort of related to this, which is basically to say that it's very hard to.
Predict exactly what type of structure is needed in the system from the outset.

So for instance, my also vision of having tasks and solutions, which is pretty much similar to what is already in the repository is, I think a good start, but you might not know exactly what types of structures you want in this type of repository, and so it's good to have the possibility of sort of allowing the users to actually construct the structure that you.
That you want in the system.
So I think I think that it's useful to think about allowing the users to construct the structure of the system in addition to just having it set by the administrators.
